Solving a general quadratic

It is possible to use the method of completing the square to solve a general quadratic \(y = ax^2 + bx + c\). So far, we have encountered examples where the leading coefficient of the quadratic is \(1\). However, it is not much more difficult to deal with a quadratic where \(a \not=1\).


Example

Solve the quadratic \(2x^2 + 12x + 4=0\) by completing the square.


Solution

We can immediately deal with the leading coefficient by dividing all the terms through by \(2\) to obtain \[ x^2 + 6x + 2 = 0. \] Now we have a similar problem to those we have seen previously. We complete the square by adding and subtracting \(\frac{b}{2}^2 = 3^2 = 9\), (or equivalently adding \(\frac{b}{2}^2\) to both the LHS and RHS). \[ \begin{eqnarray*} x^2 + 6x + 2 + 9 - 9 &= x^2 + 6x + 9 + 2 - 9 \\ &= (x+3)^2 -7 \\ &= 0. \end{eqnarray*} \] At this point we can add \(7\) to both sides, then proceed by taking square roots. \[ (x+3)^2 = 7 \implies x+ 3 = \pm \sqrt{7} \implies x = -3 \pm \sqrt{7}. \] Therefore the solutions to the quadratic are \(x = -3 + \sqrt{7}\) and \(x = -3 - \sqrt{7}.\)
